newsitem.title: FRANCE: Police defuse bomb in French post office.
newsitem.headline: Police defuse bomb in French post office.

text.p: French police defused a bomb hidden in a plastic bag and planted in a busy central post office in the Mediterranean port of Marseille on Saturday.
Police said the unidentified attackers "clearly wanted to kill" by targeting a post office during the Christmas period when people are queueing up to mail gifts and cards.
Staff spotted the three-kg (6.6 lb) dynamite bomb shortly before the post office, on the Boulevard de Strasbourg, opened in the morning.
Police said the detonator had failed to work and they were checking at what time the device had been timed to go off.
"We can't say if the bomb was planted last night, overnight or this morning," an investigator said.
"What is certain is that this is a very powerful device that would have caused major damage in the area," he added.
Police declined to speculate on who the attackers were, but police sources said there were some similarities with recent bomb attacks on the French mainland claimed by Corsican separatists.
The mayor of Marseille, Territorial Administration Minister Jean-Claude Gaudin visited the post office. Police cordoned off the area and stepped up patrols.
French security forces are on alert for possible attacks by Algerian Moslem extremists and Corsican separatists.

Troops are helping police patrol train stations and airports under the so-called Vigipirate plan after a bomb attack blamed on Algerian rebels killed four people on a Paris commuter train earlier this month.

Suspected Corsican separatists set off a bomb overnight outside the apartment of Jean Comiti, the head of the lawyers association in the Corsican town of Ajaccio, and machinegunned a gendarmerie barracks on the French Mediterranean island.

The Corsican attacks bore the hallmarks of the outlawed Corsican National Liberation Front (FLNC)-Historic Wing, which has claimed responsibility for nine bombings or machinegunnings on the holiday island in the past week.

The FLNC, which has also carried out bombings on the French mainland recently, has threatened to step up its campaign following the arrest of Corsica's best-known separatist leader who was remanded in custody in Paris on Wednesday.
Francois Santoni, head of Cuncolta Naziunalista, the FLNC's legal wing, and his lawyer girlfriend Marie-Helene Mattei were placed under investigation for attempted extortion and bomb attacks.
